Entry.0:
Pont Niepee

The New Year came in very dull.Batt, in the line

1 Tues
Entry.1: and who can say, how the year will fare
Entry.2:
I made no resolves I’m just going to plod along with a b--- all spirit

Brune Gaye
Entry.3: Shifting today but not a great distance a mile or two
Entry.4: Now sharing camp with the 18th Batt at Brune Gaye
Entry.5:
Riding on icy roads is a very ticklish job

Nieepe
Entry.7: Heavy snow storms the country looks fine
Entry.8: Making merry in an estaminet, our only form of pleasure
Entry.9:
Batt.working with the 20th take over the front line every 6 days

Rossignal
Entry.10: The aeroplanes are very quite this moon, no raids at all.
Entry.11: The 5th Brigade Concert party is a very fine show
Entry.12:
We don’t like the moon with its brightness I wish that fought battles with hatchets instead of great big guns

Cattacombs
Entry.14: A good rum issue on tonight boys all happy
Entry.15: Had a yarn to the General, he asked many questions
Entry.16:
Battalion is being relieved tonight by the 20th Batt

La Biset
Entry.17: Reporting to Brigade H.Q.full Marching order something doing
Entry.18: I am now orderly to Brigadier General Smith D.S.O C.M.G some job
Entry.19:
General visiting the front line he left at 5 AM this morn

River Lys
Entry.21: Had a look at Nutty poor old boy looks broken hearted
Entry.22: So far I’m getting on O.K with the General but I smoked all his cigarettes – REPRIMANDED
Entry.23:
For this time of the year, the weather is almost artificial it is lovely

Steenwerk
Entry.24: I am broke, for they put the cost of cables in my book it cut out my credit
Entry.25: Met a few old pals one of them was Frank Hutson M.P
Entry.26:
After all theres no drink like water for RUM is beastly stuff

Kortepyp
Entry.28: Good Bye "Brune Gaye" our stay was pleasant
Entry.29: Trois Rois Brigade H.Q now at Kortapex Camp
Entry.30:
Hustle & Bustle for tomorrow we move out of action

Neuve Eclistz
Entry.31: Left the front by train this afternoon going for a spell General gone on leave
Entry.32: Now at the town of Sumbries in a good home
Entry.33:
Went for a long walk to Bayengham I don’t ride now have no horse

Lumbres

 3 Sun

Pay Day
Entry.36: Stayed the night at the billets of the A.Vet Section
Entry.37:
Heave oh my lads the wind blows free and with it heavy rain

Bayengham
Entry.38: Doing nothing just wandering around like a lost puppy
Entry.39: Doing nothing which is very monotonous
Entry.40:
Visiting the N C O’s school at Bayengham Lieut W R Haigh Officer in Command

Columby
Entry.42: Orderly to Cpt H.W Johnson for a day or so
Entry.44:
I will be glad when the Boss gets back

Setques
Entry.45: General arrived home by motor at 8 Pip Emma
Entry.46: General decorated for the fine work done by the Brigade at Zonnebeke Glencoise
Entry.47:
Wood & Menin Rd with the Grand Belgian Croix De Guerre

Senigham
Entry.49: A nice ride on the Staffs grey pony
Entry.50: On the summit of Sunlit Hill the scene is raident
Entry.51: Everything going well, the G.O.C seems satisfied
Entry.53: There’s a nice little girl across the way
Entry.54: General busy every day with his Bilyinns
Entry.56: Sure at present its a lovely war
Entry.57: Fine day good tucker good bed so I cant grumble
Entry.58: A long ride on the staffs chestnut horse
Entry.59: Field Manouvers so I suppose we will be moving shortly
Entry.60: My Birthday kept up, with cold tea
Entry.63: Left Sumbres by car motored to Wizernes & then took train to Bailleul rested at Trois Pois
Entry.64: Back at Brune Gaye it is just like being at home
Entry.65: The front is livening up raids ect & of course heavy gun fire
Entry.66: Washing day shirts socks collars ect I’m a fair hand at Washing
Entry.67: Ironing day "ah" I am a dud at ironing
Entry.68: Met Jim Sharman & had a great yarn of old times
Entry.71: A new moon ah when its full there’ll be bombs
Entry.72: Life much the same slow & monotonous but it could be alot worse
Entry.73: Washing day and then a good ride, I looked up old friends
Entry.74: Pay day that means a drop of wine
Entry.75:
The Generals o haveing a busy time

Brune Gaye
Entry.77: A reunion of Corowa boys at Rue De Sac
Entry.78: Jim Sharman Ted Cowan Herb Freyer & Jack Hutton
Entry.79:
A big raid on the german trenches by the 18th Batt which was successful

Messines
Entry.80: The big hun offensive started this morning.Shifting today Relieving
Entry.81: Kartenyp Trois Rois Camp now our home Down near Cambrai they are fighting hard
Entry.82:
No news of the big scrap, just rumours, we are winning one hour, and next the germans hold sway, at any rate its critical "Cheerio"

Midlands
Entry.84: Relieved the 8th Bdg at Midlands on the battlefield of Messines
Entry.85: The big fight still goes n we’ve still got a fighting chance, buck up Australia
Entry.86:
Full moon, but the hun aeroplanes are very quite camped on the bounds of beggary

Wulcerghem
Entry.87: The dug out here is a bonser 50 Ft deed ½ mile long
Entry.88: Good Friday on the field but all the same I had a Hot X Bun
Entry.89:
A hard life early out of bed late back in to it, General very irritable

Metterin
Entry.91: This shifting business is a b--.Arrived at Metterin 6 PIP.EMMA
Entry.92: Hustle and bustle, I am weary and ill at ease.This place is all life
Entry.93:
Left Metterin at midnight, Marched to Castre.Left by train for the big stuff at 3 A M

Amiens
Entry.94: Arrived at Amiens 5 A M Marched to Allonville
Entry.95: Left Allonville yesterday morning now at Bussy-Le-Daux.Blangy-Tronvill
Entry.96:
Just got settled last night when along comes the order to shift, Marched 10 weary miles to a Village named Brettone, then into action at Gentellen

Hangard Wood
Entry.98: & 20 Batt attacked the huns & beat him.
Entry.99: A hail of shells all day (big uns) he has the range of this Village to a T
Entry.100:
Fritz came over last night on our right he entered Hangard but the French soon shifted him

Villiage Brettoneaux
Entry.101: A tornado of High explosives It is hard, my heart is thumping and my nerves all trembling but I am trying to be brave
Entry.102: On duty for 36 continuous hours but the job is good its that of despatch runner
Entry.103:
We are the brigade of Englishmen that are fighting with the French Attached to 58 Div

Centelles
Entry.105: After 4 hours heavy shelling we were forced to quit our quarters
Entry.106: B H Q in a chalk pit.General sent me back to Boves, living in a chateau
Entry.107:
My home is a musty old cellar my mate is a good sort, Jack Trenbeth.The boys are having a hard time.

Boves
Entry.108: It is miserable, rain and cold mists, the Brigade is being releived tonight by the Tommys
Entry.109: Left Boves after dinner and after a March of 12 Kilos we stayed at Querriu in a fine mansion
Entry.110:
Once upon a time the 
home
 of 
Count Alcantara
.On the move again.A beautiful March to Bihencourt living in a lovely chateau
Entry.112: I’ve got a bellyache but the weather is top-hole
Entry.113: Reporting back to the 17th with a good resilence the job did not beat me
Entry.114: On again going into action near Albert halting for the night at Warloy.The hun made a big attack this morning
Entry.115: Our Boys did not go into action the order was cancelled Spent the day on poker I won a few francs
Entry.116: Another full moon and a big fight soon the Brigade went into action today
Entry.117:
Taking things easy reading writing and gambling and eating good tucker, but Im lousy I scratch my self to sleep every night

Warloy

28 Sun Letters from Australia dated
Entry.120: Batt, and taking charge of old friend Nutty
Entry.121: Detailed by the C.O to report to H Q at 8 Ack Emma
Entry.122:
And the job was to escort a bonny French Girl Lily to Nanas

Querried
Entry.123: In the road again left Warloy after dinner, arriving at Montigny, just as the sun went down
Entry.124: A beautiful night & ride to the Village of Pont-Noyelles
Entry.125:
Pay day, but theres not a thing to be bought for miles & miles around Met Sid Smedly

Allonville
Entry.127: Billited at the farm of Mr Hennessy of Three Star brandy fame
Entry.128: Revisiting old friends and how delighted they are to think that a chap should recall them
Entry.129:
A long ride on (Nuttys new mate) Saxon to Querrieu

La Huoysee
Entry.130: After a good March we arrive at the town of La Huoyosse on the Amiens road
Entry.131: Shelled out of our home four men killed now at Hopeful Outlook X X with our lines in a wood, full of Tanks
Entry.132:
On the move again shifting to the forest near Freshoncourt I am being sent to hospital in the morn with boils

Vicnacourt
Entry.133: 5th Field Ambulance and then C C at Vignacourt
Entry.134: The grey dawn is breaking and I view it from the cosy cot of a Red X Train
Entry.135: Now in the 1st Aust General Hospital at the city of Rouen operated on this morning
Entry.136:
The treatment received here is fine everything so comfortable 

Rouen
Entry.137: Given a whiff of ether and then operated on the sensation was queer
Entry.138: The nurses asked the doctor could they keep me for the duration of the war
Entry.139: The Commanding Officer of this hospital is Col Dick of Randwick We had a good yarn
Entry.141: My back is as full of humor as an adders is of poison
Entry.142: Attended a concert given by Miss Lena Ashwell a good show
Entry.143: The Sisters are petting me as if I was black kitten that had strayed in
Entry.144: Bob Huttons Birthday Ordered back to bed A lot of gassed men arrived today
Entry.145: Helping Sister to dress wounds and afterwards had the knife applied to my back
Entry.146: Some of the wounds are gasthly, but it is marvellous the fortitude of the boys in bearing them.
Entry.148: My back is almost better but the wounds are not healing to well
Entry.149: The hun offensive as recommenced, a very busy day in the wards I am helping the sisters
Entry.150: It is marvellous, the ways of modern surgeons, broken men remended in an hour
Entry.151: In suspense, how goes the day, fair I should think for no casualtys have come in for 48 hours
Entry.152: The hun bombed the city of Rouen through the night The weather is just perfect.Still no caslualtys a very good omen
Entry.153: This is an ideal rest which I highly appreciate I would like to stay here for a long time
Entry.155: A big convoy in, many casualty gasthly sight.
Entry.156: Helping the doctor to sew up the wounds ect
Entry.157: Today I had a long yarn to Gen.Sir W Birdwood, he shook my hand on parting
Entry.158: Major Wooster one of natives gentlemen & one of the best I’ve net in the army
Entry.159: Great preparations being made barraceades ect, around the wards in case of air raids
Entry.160: A big crowd of wounded in, but the list is not so heavy by far as to what was expected
Entry.162: I’m busy as a honey bee doing all kinds of work
Entry.163: Clerk Runner Letter writer and the M.Os adjutant
Entry.164: A big show was given today by the Yankees very funny & good
Entry.165: When your friend quotes scripture brand your cattle
Entry.166: No letters from Australia for a long time
Entry.167: A day in Rouen which is a very interesting and pretty place
Entry.169: Here I am the right boy in the right place.They like my storys
Entry.170: Believe me it is fine to mingle with the Australian Sisters
Entry.171: The 4th Divison Concert party is a very fine show
Entry.172: A lull on the battle front, no wouned arriving Major Ferber is now our M O
Entry.173: Roses are blooming in Picardy sure France at present is a beautiful country
Entry.174: The longest day, ah well I’m strong and thank Providence no day is to long for me
Entry.176: Another full moon but the hun as been very quite with his aeroplanes
Entry.177: He threatened to have the town of Rouen in flames this moonshine but so far so good
Entry.178: I have, at this place, as at all others made good but I daresay that I will soon get Marching orders
Entry.179: The hun endeavoured an air raid on Rouen tonight, but he was beaten off by the aircraft guns
Entry.180: I can’t set my mind to letter writing, and I’ve received no letters for two months
Entry.181:
A long day 17 hours of daylight.I have made a pal of Sister Bowtell fron Deniliquine

 30 Sun

Vivtar to the Canadians
Entry.182: The American lassies are "IT", very pretty girls
Entry.183: Rumors flying about that we are preparing for a big battle, on the "Somme front.
Entry.184: To day I was marked fir for Duty, it is hard to leave
Entry.185: A big picnic on the Rouen football grounds by the Yanks Allies well represented
Entry.186: The Australian & American stunt was a big success, 2000 prisoners, and our casualtys were not very heavy
Entry.187: Now at No 2 C.Camp which is just near a big Waac’s camp and a good home
Entry.189:
Nelli Marthe Picot 

Stfl.Des Cummees 

Rouey
Entry.190:
A fine little girl, 

4 place des Luimierees

Rouey
Entry.191: Sick very sick, carried to hospital on a stretcher No 6 British Hospital
Entry.192: I’ve got a faint hope of getting to Blighty for the doctor is sending them off wholesale
Entry.193: Temperature normal but the pains are very severe my complaint is P V.O (Trench fever)
Entry.194: It is a bloody shame the way they swing the lead.
Entry.196: The treatment received in this place is bonny
Entry.197: It is good, way out here to see the flags of America & England floating in the breeze
Entry.198: Now at No 2 Con Camp in comfy quarters very nice
Entry.199: The hun is trying again for Paris but he will come a horrible gutzer
Entry.200: Today I donned the blue jersey of Australia, against South Africa in a game of rugby
Entry.201: The fight is going in our favour vague rumours keep coming through
Entry.203: A beautiful day, that makes me pine for the Australian bush
Entry.204: The hun as been very very quite with his planes this month
Entry.205: Pay day, 20 lovely francs a fortnight & a man as a credit of 23.10 0
Entry.206: Now in the hall of the Soldiers Christian Association, conversing with a Miss Carr, she wants me to be a missionary
Entry.207: I am going to write Mr Billy Hughes a letter today, nothing like trying
Entry.208: International sports were held today the Aussies almost scooped the pool Madrillel Green Hantray
Entry.210: Now in the heart of France at Buichy a huge camp
Entry.211: Everything here is OK.I am to fight for the L.W.championship
Entry.212: A cross country run through very nice country
Entry.213: Another month, and all’s well, but what of the next, who can tell
Entry.214: Good news keeps filtering through the hun is on the run so cheerio
Entry.215: A milestone three year tomorrow since I joined the army, but still we live
Entry.217: I am now a choir boy at the camp church Heavy storms
Entry.218: Here I am watching 500 men, gracefully doing the two-step
Entry.219: A cross country race of 2 1/2 miles 2000 starters I finished in the first 100, time 17 ½ Min
Entry.220: The eve, I believe of a big push by the allies, thank the Lord I.m not in it
Entry.221: The big stunt took place and success attended it, 17,000 prisoners 300 guns
Entry.222: Way out in the bush miles from anywhere with a big picnic party which includes 4 lady girls from England
Entry.224: Grouse shooting begins but we still are shooting & caging huns in large number 30,000 prisoners
Entry.225: Had a fight today with a Tommy I won but the referee thought otherwise
Entry.226: The weather is ideal and the conditions almost perfect
Entry.227: At a very fine concert and just as soon as it was over the hun made an air raid
Entry.228: Jackie the little black bloke, the real Australian and absolutely the hardest & roughest thing in France Sargent S.Sargeant 46 in A.IF
Entry.229: Out for a picnic at the wood of Monterilar The affair is arranged by the Padre (Red Dunlop)
Entry.230: Trying to tell a tale to Marie
Entry.231: 3 weeks yesterday we arrived here 500 of us with 90% dead drunk a funny story
Entry.232: Success attends all our efforts on the front very cheerful
Entry.233: The worst of this war will end with the year, about time to so cheerio
Entry.234: Harvest moon, and what a love she is bright as a happy life
Entry.235: A nice little girl last night was knocked off her bycicle & robbed by five soldiers who were Australians
Entry.236: Out blackberrying in a part of the country that resembles a flower garden
Entry.238: Trying to tell a little girl a tale but she wont listen to me
Entry.239: "I am blessed if I don’t think we are winning"
Entry.240: A beautiful day and a very interesting day for we are holding sports
Entry.241: I am as hard as a rock strong as bull active as a cat and of good heart
Entry.242: The summer Sun is on the wane and winter comes sneaking in slow but sure.
Entry.243:
"Good Boy Jackie" greets me on the football ground, at the ringside ect, everybody seems to know me and talk about me

Buschy
Entry.245: I’ve had a lovely rest, that will soon end, "ah" well never mind
Entry.246: 5 beautiful weeks of all that could be desired tomorrow I leave for the WAR steadfast & confident hopeful and happy
Entry.247:
Dawn at Buchy Station Au Revior to a fine home Now in the train bound for Harfluer, with a load of hun prisoners

Harfluer
Entry.248: Base Depot Situated in a valley of gloriousness at the rear of historic Harfluer
Entry.249: Now at the city of Le Havre at the leading hotel dining with the "Elite" I don’t care a d--- what it costs
Entry.250:
Sore feet & Heavy Storms

Le Havre
Entry.252: With my rifle on my shoulder faith theres no man could be bolder
Entry.253: Left Roulles yesterday midday still in the train, arrived at Bray for dinner then Marched
Entry.254:
15 kilos barefooted along the river Somme to the battalion at the Village of "Frize"

Somme
Entry.255: Now in the vicinity of Peronne, the country is bare but it as not suffered much from shell fire
Entry.256: Nothing much doing on this front, 2 hun planes brought down in flames.Brigade sports held
Entry.257:
Out on this sector we seem to be cut off from the world no news of anything and not even a cigarette

Cappy
Entry.259: Sports held today A great show, tote bookmakers ect
Entry.260: A swim in the "Somme" at dawn, very refreshing after a night before
Entry.261:
Heavy fighting this morn French & British advance on a 25 mile front very successful

Susanne
Entry.262: A ride on Nutty to the Village of Suzanne in quest of material for the batt banquet.
Entry.263: The aeroplanes are wonderful, hundreds in the sky day & night floating about like gulls
Entry.264:
A ride to Peronne with Major Fusell & Cpt Ronald, passing through Biaches and Fleurilles, and Cleary

Peronne
Entry.266: 3 Oclock in the morning after a long ride to Peronne.Good news from HGLand
Entry.267: Heavy cannonades in the vicinity of St Quentin evidently a barrage on the Hindenburg line
Entry.268:
A long March 30 kilos and then an advance behind tanks alongside Warfussie Rd

Frise
Entry.269: We are moving up tomorrow in quest of great adventure for we’ll attempt to take HINDENBURG line off the hun
Entry.270: Moving off tonight at 8 AM with a long March in front of us (all night).Big things in view, with every son of a gun confident of success
Entry.271:
Last night was hard a trying March (20 K) & then we slept on the lawn in full Marching order minus blankets very cold the fun starts in the morning

Longavesnes
Entry.272: The big fight commenced at 4 50 Am
Entry.273: The winter came in like a wolf on the fold, his winds they are bighting his frost "Oh so cold!
Entry.274: Going into action all roads leading to the line are nought but a seething mass of traffic having dinner at HAGINCOURT
Entry.275:
Now at the Hindenburg line at Ribequete and what I’ve seen "Oh God", makes a man sick with horror

Capt Ronald Wounded

 7.30 Am
Entry.276: The big battle is now raging barrage opened at 6.AM a good morning, we now await the result.(10 AM) Many prisoners & Still advancing
Entry.277: Fritz your beaten although our list of casualtys were 281 but you bombed us hard last night
Entry.278:
6th Brigade went over this morning on ferry prisoners Tonight the 2nd Div are being relieved I am on pick BEAUREVIOR

A gallop to Nauroy and then
Entry.279: Going out of action to Hervilly
Entry.280: Entraining at Tincourt for civilisation.The batt numbers about 190
Entry.281: After an all night ride we arrive at Vignacourt, it is raining & so cold
Entry.282:
The Angelus is ringing & pretty girls friting about, life in billets is good, after up the line

Off to Blighty
Entry.283: Wine flows free, the boys are happy song & mirth,"Marching" with the deathless army of the A.I F
Entry.284: Left Fignacourt last night, rested at St Vasbri & slept for the night at Saint Savavour then took train to Bolounge at Ailly Sur Somme
Entry.285:
Bolounge to Folkestone a very nice trip, arrived in London for tea Feet very sore.I am being sent to hospital Signal of distress ulcerated Feet

Uxbridge
Entry.287: My tootsies were lanced this morning, May be I will be here 1 week
Entry.288: Peace Peace let there be peace, but on our own terms, for the day is ours by conquest
Entry.289:
A fellow soon forgets the hardships of war when out of the fighting zones.

Harefield
Entry.290: Good news Lille Ostend and Douae fell today Sure she must end soon
Entry.291: A dinkum case in hospital gets a fair deal, but the malingers makd a chap sick of soldiering on
Entry.292:
I will be here for a few more days and then I’ll get my leave, and I guess there will be some thing doing

Hu Chin Chow H M
Entry.294: At the pictures same old love storys, same old comics
Entry.295: A beautiful walk from Denham to Uxbridge then on to London
Entry.296:
The Better Ole at the Oxford and at night Drury Lane."Shanghai" Dorrie Brunton

Scotland
Entry.297: "London, life luxury & gaiety, one can hardly realise theres a war on at all, but a fellow spends a lot of cash
Entry.298: St Pauls, Westminister and various other places of interest visited.Leaving for Ireland tonight via Stranraer
Entry.299:
In the saloon of the S.S Princess Maude doing the grand with the big bugs.Being escorted by destroyers & an airship "Laine" in sight

Derry
Entry.301: Renewing acquaintance with the wee lassies of Ireland "och sure
Entry.302: You’re a luck boy Jack to have made friends with the ONiells of Co.Derry sure tis a lovely home
Entry.303:
Off to the old town of Londonderry.Now on the old battle wall of Derry built in 1688 a very nice old place

Antrim

31 Th
Entry.304: Eve Ballycairn an old fort that overlooks the country, a beautiful sight of a beautiful land
Entry.305: A long cycle ride around the district, and then the guest of Mr & Mrs McFayden
Entry.306:
Alls Souls day and theres a soul here light & happy

Chester
Entry.308: At Raheny the home of Mr R ONiell J.P Doreen
Entry.309: Guest of the Mayor & Mayoress of Coleraine Leaving for "Scotland"
Entry.310:
Chester the best cleanest & quaintest place I’ve met in all my travels

London
Entry.311: London at dawn just waking up, but it is enveloped in a fog.
Entry.312: Hippodrome A show in aid of the Yanks", Violet Lorraine George Robey Harry Tate & many other good artists
Entry.313:
St James The eyes of youth Gertrude Elliot a fine show 

Lord Mayor of London Show

Sure this is the life A wonderful world.

St Savour
Entry.315: The troops & civilians are overjoyed the scenes are thrilling "Ah how good it is
Entry.316:
We are I believe going to Germany to do garrison work for a while, I had a fight today

Vignacourt
Entry.317: No bread jam or butter on issue for our rations as gone to feed the hungry huns
Entry.318: The French are admirable, I shall never forget them.They love the Aussies
Entry.319:
Spoken at an Aust Cemetry by the Mayor of Amiens

People of France you can never repay the debt you owe to Aust All women should be as mothers sisters wifes & sweethearts to the full by caring for their graves for all times

Aust & Amiens
Entry.321: An evening with the school mistress Mollie Albertine very interesting.(The germans shall never pass)
Entry.322: Waiting to go home, is going to be very monotonous, but when we get on the move the time will soon slip by
Entry.323:
The weather is not to bad, it is very dry for this time of the year, but by jingo it is cold heavy frost and dense fogs

Bohain

21 Th

"Vignacourt" this is the 3rd time I’ve bid you good bye 1st time when going to Pozieres
Entry.324: when going to Rouen, this time bound for Germany.Leaving by train this evening 5 PM
Entry.325: All night in train arrived at Marcoing at dawn, then on to Cambria, disentraining at Bertry then Marched on through Marety & Brisigny to Bohain at dusk, staying for a day or so
Entry.326:
The Villages about here are in fairly good order not knocked about by shellfire at all but the townhall of this town was smashed by the hun before he left & the women who have been her in the hands of Fritz for 4½ years had a hell of a time.Veneral Disease is very much prevelant

Nazzerhiem

 24 Sun 

We ought to be home next
Entry.328: 18 Kilo March through Morlain & Mazzerhiem to Ryel de Beauvil Miserable weather.Now that the war is over we realize what we’ve been through
Entry.329: Another March passed through Catallion and Le Groise to Prisches Rations very light.The tales told by the willing are very nasty
Entry.330:
A pacel of Fatty Cakes from Muriel.Thanks awfully much.I have a good home The germans were hard & harsh to the civilians

Prisches
Entry.331: Raining like hell but here I am with Rosa learning French & making her laugh, like shes never laughed for 4½ years
Entry.332: The French civilians are beaucoup mechant avie allemandes petit après la guerre nous will invade germany
Entry.333: Och sure the people on this farm are tres bon I am living altogether with them and they cannot do enough for me
Entry.334: The King paid us a visit
Entry.335: 1000 days of active service and I am as good as ever
Entry.336: La belle Mademoiselle Francais, tres chick tres bonne.Le Soldat Australie jamais oublieur votie complaison
Entry.337: "Oh" this is a great home, "Mamma Papa & Sister" who are treating me like a long lost son they reckon I am tres gentiel
Entry.338: Nutty the old b—is having a royal time good grass & stable, he reckons it is just like being at home.
Entry.339: Letters from home ar pleadings of "amour", but that sort of stuff with me is dead a mans mind as been altered with the war
Entry.341: A nice bright Sunday, had a good bath
Entry.342: The old moon is bright again, but now we have ceased to look at it with awe, good old moonlight
Entry.343: Mail very scarce, today I received a picture of Elsie nice girl Elsie but as the French say "Tres Serious Le Photo
Entry.344: A whisper, today, that I Maybe sent to England to take up a position at Horseferry Rd I’d like it yet I wont like it
Entry.345: The Educational scheme is in its infancy, but the boys seem to be out to learn and refresh their minds on all subjects
Entry.346: Good Bye Nutty good bye the
Entry.347: Batt for I am off to England today to take up a job.A long March to Vaux Andrecie where we caught a sleep in a warm stable.
Entry.348:
Boarded the leave train at 4.30 this morning at V-A proceeded to St Orente thence Amiens and crossed the battle field of V.Brettonuex

 15 Sun

France good bye RMS.Victoria
Entry.349: Appointed clerk in the Finance Dept.Horseferry Rd London.I will make good
Entry.350: London youre a great big lonely place,when a chap is stiff, nobody knows you.
Entry.351: Commencing duty in the office on the top floor plenty of pretty girls
Entry.352: A Mans first love is always his most perfect, because he has no other love to compare with it
Entry.353: Humor is the consciousness of the nothingness of anything.
Entry.354: No work until Friday A visit to Richmond to view the match (Rugby) N Zealand v.England a good game the Maoris won 16 to 0
Entry.357:
I visited the Princes Theatre "Jolly Jack Tar" good show, and then I journeyed to Hampstead and spent the evening with Mr & Mrs Pugh

25 Wed

I attended Westminister Abbey and when the royal party were leaving the church they stopped right by me, "Mary P of Wales looked nicely at me & I looked nicely at her and smiled
Entry.359: Today I witnessed the arrival of President Wilson great doings, at night I was the guest of people at Brompton but London you’re lonely with all your life
Entry.360: Letters from Elsie they were only written in June It aint a bit of use you grumbling old girl these thing will happen in a great war
